prior_works.title: Neural Message Passing for Quantum Chemistry
prior_works.authors: Justin Gilmer, Samuel S. Schoenholz, Patrick F. Riley, Oriol Vinyals, George E. Dahl
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The k_phi–k_rho–m framework abstracts and unifies link-level architectures by instantiating Gilmer et al.’s message and aggregation maps (phi, rho) for pairs of nodes, providing the base formalism the paper generalizes to link representation.

prior_works.title: How Powerful are Graph Neural Networks?
prior_works.authors: Keyulu Xu, Weihua Hu, Jure Leskovec, Stefanie Jegelka
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper extends the WL-based expressiveness analysis of Xu et al. from node/graph representations to links, using the same indistinguishability principles to compare link-level models within their hierarchy.

prior_works.title: Weisfeiler and Leman Go Neural: Higher-order Graph Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Christopher Morris, Martin Ritzert, Matthias Fey, William L. Hamilton, Jan Eric Lenssen, Gaurav Rattan, Martin Grohe
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed hierarchy mirrors higher-order WL reasoning; the k components in k_phi–k_rho–m echo k-WL-style neighborhood lifting used by Morris et al. to formalize increased expressiveness beyond 1-WL.

prior_works.title: Invariant and Equivariant Graph Networks
prior_works.authors: Haggai Maron, Heli Ben-Hamu, Nadav Shamir, Yaron Lipman
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Maron et al.’s formal treatment of invariant/equivariant architectures informs the paper’s theoretical tools for comparing link-level expressiveness and reasoning about symmetry-induced indistinguishability.

prior_works.title: Link Prediction Based on Graph Neural Networks (SEAL)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SEAL’s enclosing-subgraph modeling is explicitly subsumed by the k_phi–k_rho–m framework, serving as a key instance in the derived hierarchy and motivating the design of link-focused synthetic tasks.

prior_works.title: Inductive Relation Prediction by Subgraph Reasoning (GraIL)
prior_works.authors: Kexin Teru, Etienne Denis, William L. Hamilton
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GraIL operationalizes path/subgraph reasoning for unseen entities; it fits naturally in the unified framework and anchors the expressiveness comparisons for inductive link prediction.

prior_works.title: Modeling Relational Data with Graph Convolutional Networks (R-GCN)
prior_works.authors: Michael Schlichtkrull, Thomas N. Kipf, Peter Bloem, Rianne van den Berg, Ivan Titov, Max Welling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: R-GCN is a prototypical message-passing link predictor on knowledge graphs that the k_phi–k_rho–m framework subsumes, helping delineate how relation-aware message functions affect link expressiveness.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—a unifying k_phi–k_rho–m framework for link representation expressiveness and a principled hierarchy across link GNNs—builds on two pillars: message-passing formalism and WL/theory-driven expressiveness. Gilmer et al.’s message passing provides the primitive maps (phi for messages, rho for aggregation) that the authors reparameterize for link-centric computations, enabling a common language across diverse link models. The expressiveness lens is inherited from WL theory: Xu et al. establish the 1-WL equivalence for node/graph representations, while Morris et al. show how higher-order WL increases distinguishing power. These ideas are adapted to links, where the paper formalizes when two candidate links are indistinguishable and organizes existing methods into a hierarchy. Maron et al.’s invariant/equivariant perspective further grounds the formal tools for reasoning about symmetry, directly inspiring the paper’s graph symmetry metric that quantifies link indistinguishability in practice.
On the modeling side, the framework concretely subsumes leading link predictors: SEAL’s enclosing-subgraph approach and GraIL’s inductive subgraph reasoning become specific k_phi–k_rho–m instantiations, clarifying why and when they are more expressive than simple neighborhood-pooling baselines. R-GCN anchors the multi-relational case, showing how relation-specific message maps alter the hierarchy. These works collectively motivate the paper’s synthetic evaluation protocol tailored to link-level expressiveness, and the symmetry metric connects theory to practice by predicting when greater expressiveness yields tangible performance gains on real graphs.
